target_title: choosing a predefined color set causes loss the custom color set

note.body:
You've commented on a 10 year old issue. Since then, many other issues / feature requests have also arisen regarding the Colors tab.

It's unclear to me if in your proposal that "Custom" slot should only be short-lived (as long as the Preferences window is open, or as long as GNOME Terminal is running) or should be permanent. Anyway.

Currently we don't offer any slot for saving/restoring a palette. Your proposed solution would offer 1 unnamed, brittle slot where it's easy for those saved values to be lost. I'm not sure this would be an improvement; it might as well mislead users as we seem to promise more but not quite deliver it.

A complete overhaul of the Colors tab is long overdue, as partially already discussed in a few other issues (which I'm lazy now to look up). I think it should be redesigned and reimplemented from scratch. It should address these issues:

- Saving (with giving it a name) and loading an arbitrary amount of custom palettes.
- 3rd parties being able to ship their palettes as files (potentially in deb/rpm/etc. packages) with localizable names which would then automatically appear in the Colors tab.
- If I wish to choose let's say Solarized, I should be able to pick it at 1 place, rather than at 2 places consistently as now.
- Automatic dark/light mode switch.
- A user interface where at least the opening page is simpler than the current one (think along the lines of Ptyxis's or Black Box's color chooser), advanced customizability hidden behind a button.

and possibly more.

It's yet to happen. Until then, I don't think it makes sense to tweak the long-established behavior of "Custom": it wouldn't be time well spent for us developers, and the improvement would also be questionable.

target_title: Move FAQ and bug-reporting guidelines off of retired wiki site
Feature Request: Follow the "Always Show Scrollbars" preference in GNOME Settings

note.body:
> And also for having a unified toggle to control overlay scrollbars in all apps.

But that's exactly the problem, not all users _want_ things to be the same in all apps.

That accessibility preference disables the use of overlay scrollbars **for all applications that use them**, because overlay scrollbars can be detrimental to accessibility. But a lot of applications, particularly text-based, keyboard-navigated applications, **don't** use them in the first place, because the scrollbar is considered an important indicator of positioning within the content that should always be visible.

* VSCode always shows scrollbars
* GEdit always shows scrollbars, when the text exceeds the window dimensions in a given direction
* Evince shows no scrollbars at all, if viewing a document in paginated mode and the page fits in the window. When in Continuous mode or when viewing pages larger than the window size, it uses overlay scrollbars
* Meld uses overlay scrollbars in its directory-tree view, but always shows its custom scrollbars in comparison views, because it uses them to display markers indicating the location of differences between the compared files
* GNOME Builder uses overlay scrollbars by default, though you can switch the vertical one out for an overview map that's either auto-hide, or always-visible
* Google Chrome always shows scrollbars, in part because it uses them to mark the location of matches during find-in-page searches
* LibreOffice Writer always shows scrollbars

If there are people who want overlay scrollbars in their gnome-terminal windows, an application preference to enable/disable that is sensible. (The _accessibility_ preference should take priority, and disable them **even if** they're activated in the application.) But users shouldn't **have to** use the accessibility preferences, and force overlay scrollbars off in _ALL_ applications, just to get rid of them in gnome-terminal. Someone may be perfectly fine with overlay scrollbars in Nautilus, and Evince, and other applications navigated primarily by mouse, but still not want them in their terminal windows.

target_title: choosing a predefined color set causes loss the custom color set

note.body:
I don't really understand Egmont's objection — the proposed  change isn't incompatible with customizing built-in schemes. If you start modifying colors in any of the default sets, that palette should then immediately overwrite the existing "Custom" to become the new custom palette. The only requested change is that simply switching from "Custom" to "GNOME", then back to "Custom", doesn't replace the "Custom" palette with completely-stock "GNOME".

(Really, the issue is that there _is no_ custom palette storage, there's just the stored palette. When you select any of the presets, that preset's palette values are stored, replacing the custom ones. But having "Custom" in the dropdown list falsely implies that you can return to a previous custom palette, IOW that there is some sort of storage beyond the current palette. But in reality, selecting "Custom" never has any effect, because the current palette is _always_ the "Custom" one even if it's a copy of a preset.)

> They are adding chatbots _to the terminal_ as a glorified search through commands [emphasis by me]

I just realized I might have misunderstood what you originally said, due to common sloppy use of the term "terminal" to include the apps running inside, too.

Are they adding it to the terminal emulator itself, i.e. into their very product called "Windows Terminal"? That is, somewhere on its graphical user interface, _outside_ of the terminal emulation's character grid area, there'll be some means of searching the description/manual/help of available shell commands? (This is what I had in mind yesterday, and what I still find a bad approach.)

Or are they creating a new command that you invoke _within_ the terminal, from the shell, to perform such searches and show their results? (It just occurred to me that this could also be sloppily phrased as adding this new feature "to the terminal". In this case the feature request belongs to a separate (possibly brand new) project straight away, not any of the terminal emulators.)

Anyway, I still hold my claim that the latter is the good approach (along the lines of the `info`, `man`, `apropos` etc. commands). Actually, it could even be a standalone graphical app (like `xman`, `gnome-help` etc.) instead of a terminal-based app. But it doesn't belong to the graphical terminal emulator application itself.

---

Reimplementing an existing functionality (available either in a terminal-based or a graphical app) would be a great waste of resources, and would open up a whole can of worms. What's next? Someone else might equally be looking for a means to list a directory, find a file, rename a file, edit a file etc. in the terminal emulator's own graphical UI, rather than inside the actual emulation area that it provides? Pointless. Plus would endlessly clutter the terminal emulator's UI that we try to keep as clean as possible. Plus would not work as expected across ssh. Plus, with dozens of popular terminal emulators out there, would it be expected that many of them would join this game, thus overall reimplementing everything dozens of times?

If the functionality is not yet implemented then for the same reasons it belong to its own a terminal-based or a graphical app (easily accessible from within the terminal by typing that command's name), but not to the terminal emulator itself.

The terminal emulator is a place for hosting certain types of applications, handling their input and output. Not for replicating what those apps could do.

Roughly analogous story: Searching the web is the job of certain websites, not webbrowsers.

> Use case: I tend to forget the new equivalents of `ipconfig`

For a problem like this, great solutions already exist without anyone having to implement any new feature.

My recommendation is: Simply take notes for yourself.

Store them in a text file, in a sticky notes app, in an e-mail sent to yourself, in a designated notekeeping app; write them down with pen into a physical booklet, etc.

You can easily add any other notes you wish to have. Your favorite command line options, the mapping of command line options from the old tool to the new one, notes about the meaning of output fields, notes about repeatedly seen error messages, reminder about anything that you find important.

If you keep forgetting something, your own notes can help you much better than any piece of software, with or without AI, could.

I'm not being sarcastic, I do mean it seriously. For example, I have a text file containing my notes about how to check out, compile GNOME Terminal (as if I didn't know the latter one by heart), how to compile it with clang instead of gcc, how to renew the tokens for pushing into the official GNOME repos, how to make a release, how to generate a tarball (which is long obsolete), etc.

Use case: I tend to forget the new equivalents of `ipconfig`

The fact that there are dozens of terminal applications just shows there is a variety of features people like. None of them have all the same features.

`--help` was just an example maybe `man` pages are a better option.

Bottom line, if you think the feature is too niche/isn't suited for the defacto default terminal for GNOME, just close the issue.

What is the use case? How would you benefit from being able to quickly search the `--help` output of all your apps?

I have two main problems.

First, I don't think this feature belongs to the terminal – to one particular terminal out of dozens of popular ones. If anyone ever implements this feature, I believe it should be in the form of a terminal-based application, so that users of all terminals out there equally benefit from it.

Second, implementing it is highly problematic. On my system there are about 4500 binaries in the path, on some systems it might be significantly higher. Launching all of them with a `--help` parameter, all of them starting up and printing their help, reading and indexing these outputs takes enormous resources, would last for a few minutes probably and cause a high system load. It really should be a separate app building up and occasionally refreshing the database, similarly to `apropos` which searches in the manual pages. Plus, not every app supports `--help`, what to do with those that don't, those that execute unwanted side effects? How would you know upfronts which apps to run with a `--help` parameter and which ones not to? Because of these apps, I think this feature is not even feasible to implement.

I'm quite certain that any feature like this is way out of scope for GNOME Terminal.

Thank you for spending time investigating.

I'll spent sometime looking into ATK and see if any changes were made there. The tracking also doesn't work in gedit.

If I can find where the issue actually is I'll raise a bug there. But going to have to re-install my machine so I can get my terminal environment tracking again.
It definitely sounds like the same issue but it looks like a fix was merged 8 months ago. I still get the issue on GNOME 47. So perhaps it was something different.

I've modified the assignment of `caret` [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/-/blob/0.78.1/src/vteaccess.cc?ref_type=tags#L338) in some silly way: if bit 1 is set then flip bit 0 (a.k.a. it counts as 0, 1, 3, 2, 4, 5, 7, 6, 8...).

The magnifying window's movement follows this silly pattern.

This is a proof that VTE does not explicitly communicate the cursor position (explaining why I couldn't find this code), but some other party tries (or at least: tried in the past) to reverse engineer it from the text snapshot and the cursor's offset within.

(I'm suuuuuure it's not VTE somewhere else doing this reverse engineering when it has direct knowledge about the cursor's onscreen coordinates.)

This sounds like a terrible idea to me: no matter how hard they try and how much effort they put into getting it right, it'll never be good. I hope they removed it because they replaced it with a more robust method where the widget needs to communicate the caret's visual position, in which case we're yet to figure out how to do it and implement it.

Otherwise it's some other component (gnome-shell? mutter? orca? I don't know) that accidentally broke this heuristics and needs to bring it back (well, at least temporarily until they ditch this horrible approach and come up with a clean and robust one).

(offtopic)

> There is bug in many text fields throughout Gnome shell including Gedit where the cursor is only track if a character is to the right of the insertion point.

Could gnome-shell#7459 be relevant?

Checked on my backup computer (with Ubuntu 24.04, rather than the daily used one with 24.10).

It works in GNOME Terminal! It also works with current master (0.79) vte test app, and also with Gedit.

So it's pretty much certain that the problem is elsewhere, somewhere in some more lower level component of the GNOME stack, rather than in VTE / GNOME Terminal.

And it also means that so far I've missed one cool aspect of VTE, and I still have no clue how it communicates the cursor's visual position :)

Keeping the text cursor position at the center goes wrong if double-wide characters, TABs, or zero-width combining accents are involved, let alone BiDi. So maybe it's not a proper solution but some really dirty black magic in some component somehow trying to reverse engineer from the a11y text snapshot (including the cursor offset within) where the cursor is probably displayed on the screen (but how does it know the character size??), and maybe that unreliable black magic was intentionally removed, or just accidentally broke or is no longer compatible with VTE and Gedit?? Who knows...

I'm trying to understand how it's supposed to work, and as part of that, at least get it partially working.

When I press Alt+F2 and the "Run a Command" dialog appears, the zoom viewport is moved to the center to magnify this dialog. But I believe this is entirely within GNOME Shell (and possibly closely related components).

With various apps, including Gedit with some text being after the cursor, also various textview-related components of `gtk3-demo`, and several other random apps (like the filesystem path at the top of Nautilus) I can't get it working, the zoomed viewport never changes automatically for me to bring the caret into the viewport.

I've checked out Gedit's source, including its foundation `libgedit-gtksourceview` as well as `gedit-plugins`, absolutely no relevant match for the case-insensitive word "caret" which I believe a corresponding API would most likely use.

Also, during my web searches about gtk and text caret tracking, I've failed to find what API would notify the windowing environment or the accessibility subsystem about the text cursor (caret) position in pixels. What I've found within VTE's source, namely `emit_text_caret_moved()` and related bits for gtk3 and `vte_accessible_text_cursor_moved()`/`gtk_accessible_text_update_caret_position()` for gtk4 are both about the caret's character offset within the 1-dimensional text snapshot string, not about its pixel position on the UI.

Without this missing piece, the caret is just a small part of the canvas that happens to be painted as a vertical bar or a solid rectangle of a prominent color, but doesn't carry the _semantics_ of being a text caret towards any observer of the terminal window.

I'm wondering: what am I missing??

Do you have a concrete sequence of steps that I could follow with a brand new account on Ubuntu 24.04 or 24.10 that shows me this feature working in _any_ app (which is not a built-in stuff like Alt+F2)?

Ah, yes. I did typo the version numbers. I've corrected them.

Here is a screen shot of the about screen for the version on Fedora 41. I think this is gnome-terminal.
![Screenshot_From_2024-11-03_13-38-25](/uploads/7e28c5adfe034e91b09466bbbd58cc5c/Screenshot_From_2024-11-03_13-38-25.png)

On Fedora 40 I have the following in About.

![Screenshot_from_2024-11-03_14-05-35](/uploads/84ec1ceda91caed814017c079caccc53/Screenshot_from_2024-11-03_14-05-35.png)

This definitely used to work.

There is bug in many text fields throughout Gnome shell including Gedit where the cursor is only track if a character is to the right of the insertion point. I've been trying to track that down for ages but still don't know which project it is in.

Are you sure this used to work?

I've tried vte test app versions 0.78, 0.74 and 0.70 (on Ubuntu 24.10) and it doesn't work in any of them.

In order for this to work, the terminal has to keep telling to the windowing enrivonment (GNOME Shell / Mutter / alike) where its text cursor is. I can't recall ever coming across such an API, let alone VTE / GNOME Terminal using it. I might have simply missed it, though.

If there indeed exists such an API, we might hook up to it in order to continuously let the windowing environment know where our text cursor is, to let that do with this information whatever it wants to.

---

I've randomly tried `gedit` and the text cursor isn't followed there, either. Nor is the dialog (whether to save the file before quitting) automatically brought into viewport, something that I'd have expected to be handled by GTK (if such a feature indeed exists). I'm not sure if it's supposed to work with `gedit` and haven't tried other apps. But I'm wondering: could it be a regression (or deliberate feature removal) in the windowing environment and/or GTK, rather than in GNOME Terminal / VTE?

Could you please give an example where this feature works, just for curiosity, so I can try and test it? :)

---

On a side note:

A feature like this is, in the context of terminal emulators, is necessarily prone to occasional (rare) unwanted flickers. When updating the text somewhere, the cursor almost always has to go there in order to print letters (there are a few escape sequences that perform scrolling or similar operations which doesn't require the cursor to go to the area where the change happens, but it's pretty hopeless to drive complex changes using such sequences). The terminal emulator receives the data from the app in a continuous stream, with possible short breaks potentially anywhere (due to auto-flushing buffered output, process scheduler kicking in, fragmenting into network packets and some being delayed, etc.).

Example: Maybe you're typing text to Vim's topmost line, but the row/column indicator in the bottom row is also updated after every letter. The cursor needs to go down there momentarily, yet the zoomed-in part automatically following it would be unpleasant.

The terminal emulator would have to apply some heuristics as to when to update the windowing environment's notion about the cursor position and when to delay this a bit, possibly with a somewhat larger delay than one UI frame (which VTE uses at a couple of other places), not sure what the best strategy would be, but it'll always be prone to some rare flickers.

I guess you mean gnome 46/47 not 36/37?

Are you sure this is gnome terminal? AFAIK fedora has replaced gnome-terminal with a different terminal; please check the Help, About menu item.
This has nothing to do with `gnome-terminal`? :)

target_title: Feature Request: set tab header colours via control codes / tab icons

note.body:
To make using this easier, I [patched ImageMagick](https://gitlab.gnome.org/chpe/ImageMagick/-/commits/) to allow setting the sixel image ID; use it like this:
```
convert test.png -define sixel:id=65535 sixel:-
```

target_title: GLib-GIO-CRITICAL when the command string contains "???"

note.body: Also note that the process ID changes between the two cases (36460, 36612) whereas the terminal's obviously stays the same.

target_title: GLib-GIO-CRITICAL when the command string contains "???"

note.body:
Since the messages are printed inside the terminal, these aren't errors/warnings of the terminal itself. Errors/warnings emitted by the terminal emulator wouldn't appear here.

Rather, someone else (the shell or some utility started from there, e.g. command-not-found handler, or the prompt if the previous command failed) prints these messages. That other utility asks the terminal to print these errors/warnings, and the terminal obeys and prints them as it has to. Also that certain component prevents the next prompt from appearing which shouldn't happen either.

Not a bug in the terminal. Check your shell's configuration.
